text:
Filling and Wrapping Unit Overview

Click here to view the Filling and Wrapping Unit Planning Chart (including pacing, key terms, materials and resources)

Unit Description

The overarching goals of the Unit are to develop students’ (1) understanding of surface area and volume for common three-dimensional shapes, and of circumference and area of circles; (2) strategies for calculating those measures for prisms, circles, cylinders, spheres, and cones; and (3) skill in application of area and volume concepts to solving measurement problems.

There are three main structural parts of this Unit. Investigations 1 and 2 build on student knowledge about surface area and volume of rectangular prisms and extend these understandings and skills to other three-dimensional shapes, including right prisms. Investigation 3 develops and applies formulas for circumference and area of circles. To strengthen understanding of area and circumference of circles, students use this knowledge to investigate cylinders. While the primary shapes of this Unit are prisms and circles, Investigation 4 deepens students’ understanding of prisms and circles to develop and apply formulas for surface area and volume of cylinders, spheres, and cones. Applying their knowledge of volume of prisms to develop strategies for volume of shapes that are not prisms strengthens students’ understanding of prisms. These shapes will be revisited with more complexity in the 8th grade Say It With Symbols Unit.

As with all of the CMP4 Units, one Mathematical Reflection guides the development of the understanding of the mathematical ideas in the Unit.

Mathematical Reflection

In this Unit we are exploring measurements of two- and three-dimensional shapes and how these measurements are used to solve real-world problems. At the end of this Investigation,

What do you know about measurements of two- and three-dimensional shapes?

Summary of Investigations

Investigation 1: Building Smart Boxes: Rectangular Prisms

This Investigation has three Problems. Problem 1.1 provides an opportunity to diagnose and review student understanding of surface area and volume of a rectangular prism, which was developed in the Grade 6 Unit Covering and Surrounding. Problem 1.2 uses the challenge of minimizing packaging cost to extend student understanding of volume and surface area calculation for rectangular prisms. Problem 1.3 extends students understanding of area and volume of rectangular prisms by scaling up the dimensions to create similar boxes (scale figures), which strengthens their proportional reasoning and their understanding of area and volume of right prisms. Proportional reasoning is a theme that runs throughout the 7th grade units.

Investigation 2: Connecting Rectangular Prisms to Polygonal Prisms

This Investigation has three Problems. Problem 2.1 engages students in a hands-on experiment to discover interesting relationships between the surface area and volume of different prisms—if the height of the prism and the perimeter of its base are constant, the figure whose base has the most sides will have the greatest surface area and greatest volume. For many students, this is a counter-intuitive result. However, it is similar to what students discovered when they compared areas of rectangles with fixed perimeter but different dimensions. It is surprising to students that the same piece of stiff paper can be folded in different ways to give solids with different volumes. Problem 2.2 guides students to generalize the layering strategy they used for finding volume of rectangular prisms to a strategy for finding volumes of other right prisms. The general principle is that all such volumes can be calculated as the product of the height and the area of the base. In Problem 2.3, students visualize the shapes (both 2 and 3-dimensional) that are formed when rectangular prisms are sliced by planar “knives.”

Investigation 3: Area and Circumference of Circles

This Investigation has four Problems, all focused on developing student understanding of the relationships among the radius (and diameter), circumference, and area of a circle. Problem 3.1 asks students to explore the ratio of radius and diameter to circumference for a collection of circular objects, leading to a conjectured formula for those calculations C = πd. Problem 3.2 engages students in an experiment to find which paper towel is the most absorbent. Drops of water on the towel form circular shapes. Students measure this circular area by laying a transparent grid on the wet spot and counting grid squares that fall within the circles. Student strategies such as the number of radius squares are needed to cover a circle lead to the formula A = πr2. Problem 3.3 uses a well- known dissection argument to connect circumferences and areas of circles by showing how you can reassemble sectors of a circle into a shape that is almost a parallelogram.

The motivation for considering circles in a Unit on solid figures is the essential role of circles in defining and measuring cylinders. In Problem 3.4 students develop formulas for surface areas and volumes of cylinders. Because cylinders are closely related to prisms, this reinforces what students have learned about prisms by looking at non prisms. As the number of sides of a right prism increases the shape of the prism approaches that of a cylinder which also has a greater surface area than any right prism with the same height and perimeter of the base. They also see that the volume of a cylinder can be calculated using a familiar principle—multiplying the area of the base by the height. The volume of a cylinder is greater than the volume of a right prism with the same height and perimeter of the base. This reinforces their understanding of the volumes of prisms and again relies on knowledge about the area of a circle.

Students connect their knowledge of nets for prisms to analyze nets for cylinders. They derive a formula for surface area of a cylinder by using what they know about the circumference and area of a circle. Looking at examples and non-examples of a concept is a well-established learning principle. Each problem in this Investigations has several applications of circumference and/or area of circles.

Investigation 4: Designing Packages: More Three-Dimensional Shapes

In Problem 4.1 students explore a packaging problem the involves designing cylindrical and rectangular containers that have the same volume. Comparing the surface areas of a prism and cylinder with the same volume pushes students to think about how surface area might vary and whether there is an optimal design for a given volume. The next two Problems in this Investigation build naturally on students’ understanding of surface area and volume of a prism and cylinders to extend these understandings to surface area and volume to two other well-known three-dimensional shapes, cones and spheres. In Problem 4.2 students conduct an experiment to explore the relationship among cylinders, cones and spheres that have the same height and dimeter. This leads to generalization for finding formulas for the volume of cones and spheres by referring to a cylinder with the same dimensions. In Problem 4.3 students look at ice cream containers in the shapes of cylinders, cones, and rectangular prisms that have the same dimensions. They then explore the effects of a scoop of ice cream in the shape of a sphere that is allowed to melt on the volume of the container. That is, how much of volume is occupied by the melted ice cream?

Mathematical Overview

Key Ideas: Dimensions, surface area, volume, radius, diameter, circumference, prism, cylinder, sphere, cone, scaling, cross sections

Major Focus: Geometry and Measurement

Strategic Connections: Proportional Reasoning

In Filling and Wrapping students expand on the understandings gained in Covering and Surrounding, where the investigations explored the differences and relationships between one- and two-dimensional measurements, in that case, perimeter and area. Now they extend these understandings to relationships between two- and three-dimensional measurements, in this case, surface area and volume of prisms and cylinders. Measurements of circles are investigated as an essential to understanding cylinders, and students develop formulas for area and circumference of circles. Non-prisms are introduced to allow students to make comparisons with and strengthen understandings about prisms.

Synthesizing these measurement ideas with proportional reasoning concepts from Comparing and Scaling and Stretching and Shrinking, students explore the effect on volume if one, two, or three measurement dimensions are scaled up. Additionally, the idea of minimizing a surface area for a fixed volume echoes an idea that students first encountered in Variables and Patterns.

Students do not have many opportunities in academic classes to develop spatial visualization. One problem in Filling and Wrapping focuses on this, with hands-on activities to scaffold insights about the shapes created when a plane intersects, or slices across, a prism.

In roughly this order students:

  • Relate surface areas and volumes for right rectangular prisms, especially optimization of surface area for fixed volume.
  • Predict the effects of scaling dimensions on linear, surface area, and volume measures of prisms and other three-dimensional shapes.
  • Develop and use formulas to calculate surface areas and volumes of polygonal prisms by relating them to rectangular prisms.
  • Develop spatial visualization by describing the results of slicing three-dimensional figures.
  • Extend understanding of area as covering a figure and perimeter as surrounding a figure to circles.
  • Explore the relationship between circle radius (or diameter) and circumference and area.
  • Investigate the connection of π to circumference and area calculations.
  • Investigate the relationship between area and circumference of a circle.
  • Extend the understanding of circles to explore the surface area and volume of cylinders.
  • Investigate the relationship between volumes of a cylinder, cone, and sphere with the same height and diameter.

Surface area and volume of prisms: Relationships and formulas

Developing formulas

In Covering and Surrounding students investigated the measurement of rectangular prisms. Problem 1.1 revisits this idea as a way of focusing on the base layer and height as crucial measurements in finding the volume of any prism.

The three prisms (boxes) shown above have the same base area 4 x 5 or 20 square units. The volumes are found by multiplying by the number of layers, using the same unit. Thus, the volumes are 20 x 1, 20 x 2, and 20 x 5 cubic units.

This strategy generalizes to finding the volume of any (right) prism:

Volume = Base area x Height

Examples below:

The base is a triangle, with

A = ½ (8 x 5) or 20 square inches.

The Volume = Base Area x Height = 20 x 12 or 240 cubic inches.

The base is a hexagon, with A = 166 square inches.

The Volume = 166 x 12 or 1992 cubic inches.

Relationships among base, surface area, and volume

Prisms have two bases (top and bottom) and several lateral (side) faces.

Surface area of any prism = areas of the two bases + areas of lateral faces

For right prisms the lateral faces are all rectangles. Or we can think of the lateral faces as one wraparound rectangle as in the sketches below.

Example: Can regular prisms have the same lateral area and height but different surface areas and volumes?

In the sketches above the bases have the same perimeter, 60, but the shapes of the bases are different. In Covering and Surrounding students explored the idea that a fixed perimeter can enclose different rectangular areas. In this case, covering the polygonal bases with a grid and estimating the base area will show they have different areas. (See Optimizing below for calculations.) Since the base areas are different, the surface areas will be different, even though the lateral areas are the same.

The heights of the prisms are the same, h. Since Volume = Base area x Height, the volumes will be different if the base areas are different. (See calculations for base areas below.)

Circles and Cylinders: Relationships among radius, diameter, circumference, area, and volume

Measuring Circles

As with all measurement ideas, estimation is important to help students grasp the meaning of the attribute being measured and understand the appropriate unit to use. In the case of circles students use string and a grid to estimate circumference and area.

One-dimensional measures: Circumference, diameter, radius

Students discover that the length of the circumference is a little more than 3 times the diameter length (or 6 times the radius) for any circle.

The exact multiple is, of course, pi.

The Circumference C = πD or 2 πr. Students can use an approximation for π in calculations.

FUTURE LINK: Students will investigate irrational numbers in Looking for Pythagoras, and find out that π is also irrational, that is, it cannot be expressed as any repeating or terminating decimal or fraction.

Two-dimensional measure: Area

Students explore estimation strategies.
Strategy 1: Estimate by counting whole grid squares and summing partial squares.

Strategy 2: The circle is greater than the enclosed circle (4 x 4) and less than the enclosing circle (6 x6), so average these:

A = 52 ÷ 2 = 26 units2.

Relating area and radius measures

Strategy 3: The area of the “radius square” is 9 square units. A little more than 3 of these “radius squares” cover the circle.

For any circle, area ≈ 3 radius2

As before the multiplier is π.

Area of a circle = πr2

Relating circumference and area

Students can experimentally find a relationship between circumference and area by comparing measurements for several circles.

Or we can compare two arrangements of the same area as below.

tiles.title: Area of a circle using slices

text:
The area on the left is a circle.

The area on the right is approximately a parallelogram with a base that is about half the circumference, C/2, and a height that is approximately r.

The area of the parallelogram equals (C/2)r.

Thus, the area of the circle = (C/2)r.

We can confirm this result using some algebra, though this manipulation may be beyond students at this point.

C = 2 πr and A = πr2.

Notice the common factor of πr.

A = (πr)r and C = 2(πr).

Rewriting the latter as πr = C/2, we can rewrite the Area of a circle as

A = (C/2) r.

Example: Given the circumference of a circle is 60 inches find the area.

Using C = 2 πr, we get 60 = 2 πr, so r = 60/(2π) ≈ 9.55 inches.

Using A = πr2 and r = 9.55, then A ≈ 286.5 inches2.

Measuring Cylinders, Cones, and Spheres

Three-dimensional measure: Volume of a cylinder

A cylinder is not a prism, which by definition has a polygon for a base. But the same strategy for volume works: find the area of the base layer, then multiply by the number of layers.
Base area = πr2

Volume = Base area x height

= πr2h

Surface Area = Lateral area + 2 base areas

= 2πrh + 2 πr2
Example: What is the surface area and volume of a cylinder with the lateral area and height shown below? What are the surface area and the volume if the height is 20 units?

If the circumference of the base is 60 units, then the radius is 9.55 units and the base area, A, is 286.5 square units (See previous section "Measuring Circles".)

V = Ah = 286.5h cubic units.

Surface area = 2(πr2) + Ch

= 2(286.5) + 60h square units

If the height is 20 units, then the V = 5730 cubic units and S.A.surface area = 1773 square units.

Example: Is possible to find another cylinder with the same volume, 5730 cubic units, as the above cylinder? Does it have the same surface area?

If V = 5730 and V = πr2h then h = 5730/( πr2 ).

S.A. = 2πr2 + 2πrh.

Suppose r = 9, then h = 5730/(81π)=22.5.

S.A. = 2π(81) + 2π(9)(22.5) = 1781.3.

This cylinder with a radius of 9 has the same volume but different surface area as the given cylinder.

The table below shows cylinders with radii less than and more than 9.55. As radius increases, height decreases in order to keep the same volume, 5730 cubic units.

The surface areas vary. We see that as the radius increases beyond 9.55, the S.A. increases.

Below are sketches of nets for two cases, r = 10 and h = 18.44, and r = 20 and h = 4.55. We know they hold the same volume but the surface areas are dramatically different.

tiles.title: Cylinders with same volume, different surface area

text:
Relationships among cylinders, cones, and spheres

Using clay to make a sphere and paper filled with rice to make a cone, both with the same height and diameter as a given cylinder, students discover that the volumes are related.
Since we know Vcylinder= πr2h this gives us formulas for these other non-prisms.
Note: For the sphere h = 2r, this equation can also be written as Vsphere = (4/3)πr3.

Strategic Connections: Scaling, Optimizing Volume or Surface Area

Scaling

In Stretching and Shrinking students investigated the impact of scaling a dimension on the measurements (and shape) of a Mugwump.

Example: What is the effect on the volume if we double the length, width, or height (or all three dimensions) of a rectangular prism?

B (base area) = 4 x 2 = 8.

V = BH = 8 x 5 = 40 cubic units.

If one side is doubled,

B (base area) = 2 x 8 = 16.

V = BH = 16 x 5 = 80 cubic units.

If all three dimensions are doubled,

B (base area) = 8 x 4 = 32.

V = BH = 32 x 10 = 320 cubic units.

In general, increasing one side by a factor of n increases the volume by a factor of n; increasing two sides by a factor of n increases the volume by a factor of n2 ; increasing three dimensions by a factor of n increases the volume by a factor of n3.

As you can see above, making sketches helps to visualize what is happening to the volume.

Scaling cylinders

Scaling up the radius only or the height only impacts the volume of a cylinder differently.

Example: How is the volume of any cylinder impacted by doubling the height? By doubling the radius?
When you double the height of the cylinder, the volume is doubled.

When you double the radius of the cylinder, the volume is multiplied by 4.

In general, scaling the height by a factor of n will change the volume of a cylinder by the same factor n. Scaling the radius by a factor of n will change the volume by a factor of n2.

Spatial visualization

We know that if you slice a right prism horizontally then all the cross sections will be identical to the bases. That is, part of the definition of a right prism and the calculation of volume depends on this idea of identical layers.

But what if we slice the prism at another angle? A slice is like a plane intersecting the figure.

Example: What are some shapes that are possible for a slice across a rectangular right prism?

It is important to note the number of faces intersected by the slice. Some possibilities are:

Triangle

Scalene

Quadrilateral

Opposite sides are parallel and angles are all right angles. This is a rectangle.

Pentagon

Not regular

Note: Other triangles, quadrilaterals (non-rectangular), pentagons, and hexagons are also possible.

You can find other examples of shapes that result from slicing a rectangular prism here: https://www.bgsu.edu/content/dam/BGSU/nwo/documents/camp/June10-2016/Slicing-a-Cube.pdf

Optimizing Volume or Surface Area

In Variables and Patterns students explored the possible rectangular areas with a fixed perimeter. They found that a square surrounded more area than any rectangle with the same perimeter.

Example: If regular prisms have the same perimeter, lateral area, and height, how do we maximize the volume? (Recall the previous example for regular prisms with perimeter of 60.)
For the hexagonal prism, the base is made of 6 triangles which each have same area. So,

Note: To calculate the area of the triangle and hexagon we need the Pythagorean theorem. Estimates work.

In general, for the same perimeter, as the number of sides of the base increases the area increases, and so does the volume.

Example: Compare the volume of a cylinder with base perimeter 60 and height h to prisms with the same measurements.

We already calculated that if the circumference of a circle is 60 units, the radius will be 9.55 units. (See example in previous section)

Note: Base area of the cylinder is measured in square units and the volume of the cylinder is measured in cubic units.

In general, a cylinder with the same perimeter and height as a polygonal prism will have a larger base area and volume.

Example: What is the minimum surface area for a rectangular prism with a volume of 24 cubic units?

This organized list shows the combinations of factors of 24 (1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 12, 24) that we can substitute for L, W, H to make a product of 24. (Repeats are not shown.)

A sketch of a net helps with the calculation of surface area, and also helps students improve their spatial visualization skills. The net for the 1 x 4 x 6 prism is shown below.

Notice that opposite sides are identical; the structure of the calculation shows this.

For a 1 x 4 x 6 prism, the surface area = 2(1 x 4) + 2(4 x 6) + 2(1 x 6) = 68 square units.

For whole number lengths, the 2 x 3 x 4 rectangular prism has the least surface area.

The closer we can come to a cube shape holding the same volume, the less the surface area will be.

LINK TO THE FUTURE: If we had used non-whole number lengths then a cube with sides of cube root 24, or approximately 2.9, would hold 24 cubic units, and each side would have an area of 2.92 for a surface area of 6(2.92) or approximately 50.5 square units.

Square roots and cube roots are introduced in the 8th grade Looking for Pythagoras Unit.

Unit Arc of Learning

This Unit builds on students’ prior understanding of surface area and volume of rectangular prisms to explore surface area and volume of other three-dimensional shapes, including right prisms. Students also expand their understanding of area and perimeter of two-dimensional polygonal shapes to explore area and circumference of circles. Their understanding of circles and right prisms is strengthened as they explore examples of non-right prisms such as cylinders, cones, and spheres. These latter shapes are explored in more depth in the 8th grade Say It With Symbols Unit.

Mathematical Goals for the Unit

Note: Objectives in bold text are relevant to the current investigation.

Investigation 1: Building Smart Boxes: Rectangular Prisms

Students will be working to develop elements of the following Unit Goals throughout Investigation 1.

Surface Areas and Volumes of Three-Dimensional Shapes Including Polygonal Prisms: Understand surface areas and volumes of three-dimensional shapes and how they are related.

  • Deepen understanding of volumes and surface areas of rectangular prisms
  • Estimate and calculate surface areas and volumes of polygonal right prisms by relating them to rectangular prisms
  • Relate surface areas and volumes for right prisms and non-prisms, especially optimization of surface area for fixed volume
  • Predict the effects of scaling dimensions on side lengths, surface area, and volume measures of prisms and other three-dimensional shapes
  • Recognize that volumes of prisms and cylinders can be calculated as the product of the area of the base and the height
  • Use an algebraic expression to express the volume and surface area of prisms and cylinders
  • Solve problems involving surface areas and volumes of three-dimensional shapes
  • Describe a two-dimensional shape that results from slicing a three-dimensional shape

Area and Circumference of Circles: Understand the areas and circumferences of circles and how they are related

  • Relate area of a circle to covering a figure and circumference to surrounding a figure
  • Estimate and calculate areas and circumferences of circles
  • Explore the relationship between circle radius (or diameter) and circumference and between circle radius (or diameter) and area
  • Investigate the connection of π to area calculation by estimating the number of radius squares needed to cover a circle
  • Investigate the relationship between area and circumference of a circle
  • Extend the understanding of circles to explore the surface area and volume of cylinders
  • Solve problems involving areas and circumferences of circles

Investigation 2: Connecting Rectangular Prisms to Polygonal Prisms

Students will be working to develop elements of the following Unit Goals throughout Investigation 2.

Surface Areas and Volumes of Three-Dimensional Shapes Including Polygonal Prisms: Understand surface areas and volumes of three-dimensional shapes and how they are related.

  • Deepen understanding of volumes and surface areas of rectangular prisms
  • Estimate and calculate surface areas and volumes of polygonal right prisms by relating them to rectangular prisms
  • Relate surface areas and volumes for right prisms and non-prisms, especially optimization of surface area for fixed volume
  • Predict the effects of scaling dimensions on side lengths, surface area, and volume measures of prisms and other three-dimensional shapes
  • Recognize that volumes of prisms and cylinders can be calculated as the product of the area of the base and the height
  • Use an algebraic expression to express the volume and surface area of prisms and cylinders
  • Solve problems involving surface areas and volumes of three-dimensional shapes
  • Describe a two-dimensional shape that results from slicing a three-dimensional shape

Area and Circumference of Circles: Understand the areas and circumferences of circles and how they are related

  • Relate area of a circle to covering a figure and circumference to surrounding a figure
  • Estimate and calculate areas and circumferences of circles
  • Explore the relationship between circle radius (or diameter) and circumference and between circle radius (or diameter) and area
  • Investigate the connection of π to area calculation by estimating the number of radius squares needed to cover a circle
  • Investigate the relationship between area and circumference of a circle
  • Extend the understanding of circles to explore the surface area and volume of cylinders
  • Solve problems involving areas and circumferences of circles

Investigation 3: Area and Circumference of Circles

Students will be working to develop elements of the following Unit Goals throughout Investigation 3.

Surface Areas and Volumes of Three-Dimensional Shapes Including Polygonal Prisms: Understand surface areas and volumes of three-dimensional shapes and how they are related.

  • Deepen understanding of volumes and surface areas of rectangular prisms
  • Estimate and calculate surface areas and volumes of polygonal right prisms by relating them to rectangular prisms
  • Relate surface areas and volumes for right prisms and non-prisms, especially optimization of surface area for fixed volume
  • Predict the effects of scaling dimensions on side lengths, surface area, and volume measures of prisms and other three-dimensional shapes
  • Recognize that volumes of prisms and cylinders can be calculated as the product of the area of the base and the height
  • Use an algebraic expression to express the volume and surface area of prisms and cylinders
  • Solve problems involving surface areas and volumes of three-dimensional shapes
  • Describe a two-dimensional shape that results from slicing a three-dimensional shape

Area and Circumference of Circles: Understand the areas and circumferences of circles and how they are related

  • Relate area of a circle to covering a figure and circumference to surrounding a figure
  • Estimate and calculate areas and circumferences of circles
  • Explore the relationship between circle radius (or diameter) and circumference and between circle radius (or diameter) and area
  • Investigate the connection of π to area calculation by estimating the number of radius squares needed to cover a circle
  • Investigate the relationship between area and circumference of a circle

Students will be working to develop elements of the following Unit Goals throughout Investigation 4.
